prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Practical Advice for Protecting Confidential Business Information

para.paratext: All documents related to issues of confidentiality and non-competition should be filed as part of an employee's personnel record. Such documents should be as detailed as possible and should demonstrate that the employee is well aware of his or her duties with regard to issues of confidentiality and non-competition. The employer's position in upholding the confidential nature of information will only be as strong as the evidence which demonstrates that the employee was aware of the status of the information, and that is best accomplished by an acknowledgment, signed by the employee, which demonstrates receipt of a copy of the information and any accompanying company policy.

The best protection will be to obtain an employment agreement whereby the employee specifically agrees to maintain information in confidence. The more specific the description of the confidential information covered by the agreement the better. On the other hand, the wording of any confidentiality clause should also be broad enough to include most types of confidential information. Other company documents such as employee manuals or policy statements can also be used to demonstrate that an employee was aware of the confidential status of information.
In maintaining personnel files, employers would be wise to keep in mind the standard test used by the courts to determine whether an employee has breached the duty of confidentiality:
Did the employer in fact possess and exercise a secret process?
Did the employee, during the course of employment, know that this process was secret?
Did the employee acquire knowledge of that secret or a material part thereof during his or her employment?
Has the employee, since leaving the employer's business, made an improper use of the confidential knowledge acquired?[1]
